benchmark_details.name: Entropy-Memorization Law
benchmark_details.overview: This paper presents the Entropy-Memorization Law, which characterizes the relationship between data entropy and memorization difficulty in LLMs, offering a method to distinguish between training and testing datasets, enabling dataset inference.

purpose_and_intended_users.goal: To explore how to characterize memorization difficulty of training data in LLMs and to develop a method for distinguishing training from testing data.

data.source: OLMo family of open models and their associated datasets.

methodology.calculation: Levenshtein distance measures the differences between responses and answers at the token level.
methodology.interpretation: Higher memorization scores indicate lower similarity between generated responses and reference answers.
methodology.baseline_results: Pearson r values reached up to 0.972 in testing.
methodology.validation: Algorithm validated through regression on experimental data from the OLMo models.

targeted_risks.harm: Potential privacy leakage and risks of proprietary data exposure.

ethical_and_legal_considerations.data_licensing: All datasets used are licensed under Open Data Commons Attribution License (ODC-By).
